div.ab:

the investigator of truth may thereby be admonished, and led as it were by
the hand into the right path: of these this emblematicallemblematical inscription is one,

and made Physicall by long præparation: Saturne is the father of all the-
gentiles, or rather golden things, and the first gate of secrets: With this, Sayth
Rhasis in his Epistle, are the gates of Sciences opened: His Sonne Jupiter-
Succeeds him, who expellsexpels his father out of his kingdomekingdom, and dismembreddismembered him,
that hee might not beget more Sonns; but Venus the most beautifullbeautiful of wo
men sprung from his testicles being cast into the Sea: From Jupiter, who is
hott lead præpared, are produced the other Planets, as Mars from Juno, Mer
cury from Maja, the daughter of Atlas as mountaine of Mauritania,-
Luna and Sol from Latona: which four are brought into the world by coc
tion alone or womens worke: but by coction, maturation and the dispersion
of the more crude parts is signifydsignified, which is performdperformed by Vulcan in Philo
sophicall vessells: for its is not to be supposdsupposed, that it is vulgar coction, as to-
the way of operating, but it agrees with it as to the end: For as a woman ma
tures fish in water, this is, softens, boyles and seethssees them, all the superfluous mois
ture being resolved from them into water and aire, Soe the Philosopher handles
his subject, macerating, melting, dissolving, coagulating and fixing it in a pecu
liar water, which is stronger than the sharpest vinegar, in the vessell of Her
mes, the joynts of which are most exquisitely close, as is requisite, that the wa
ter may not exhale, and that, which is in the vessell, be burned: This is-
Discourse 22.
that vessell above the vessell, and the Philosophers pott, the Laconian bath,
in which the old man sweats: Some there are, who boyle fish, Lobsters, Crabs,
or green Peas in a double, soe that the sayd things are in the upper pott, and
water onely in the lower, and the potts are placed one above the other with
orbesorbs, that the vapour may not goe forth: by which means the vapour of-
the water ascending onely penetrates and matures the things contained,-
and makes them much more tender and soft, than if they had boyled in-
water: This is the most laudable way of the Philosophers, whereby they
mollify that which is hard, dissolve that which is compact, and rarefy that
which is thicke: For the aire or insensible vapour is that which matures,-
cocts, and perfects fruits in trees, not crude and cold water, as such: The-
aire is allso that which tingethtinges and colourethcolors the golden apples in the Or
chards of the Hesperides: For, if it wee well considered, the ebullition of
water, whereby raw flesh is cocted till it be fitt to eat, is nothing els, but a ra
refaction and transmutation of the water into an airy vapour, the bubbles
being aire containdcontained within the water, which doe easily vanish away, the
aire betaking itselfe from the water to its owne Sphere, and the water-
settling to its owne center. . . . . . . . . .
